awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Emergence of Linguistic Structure in a Family Homesign Language
awd_abstract_narration:
What would a language created completely from scratch look like? This question cannot be answered by studying spoken languages, whose origins extend back into prehistory. However, sign languages continue to be created in the present day wherever a critical mass of deaf individuals forms. Thus, newly emerging sign languages provide researchers the opportunity to observe the process of language creation directly. This research project focuses on one such sign language, created by three deaf siblings and four of their hearing family members. This homesign language began as an idiosyncratic gesture system developed by the first deaf individual born into the family and was later elaborated into a shared sign system by later-born deaf and hearing family members. This research project sets out to document the grammatical structure of the language, focusing on the ways in the which the sign system of the first-born deaf individual differs from those of the later-born signers. This approach has the potential to shed light on how grammatical structure emerges and develops at the earliest stages of language creation.

This research project focuses on two grammatical structures that have been documented in nearly all sign languages studied to date: (i) classifier constructions and (ii) directional verbs. Classifier constructions represent the motion and location of objects in space and involve a meaningful handshape unit that identifies the category of the object. The inventory of classifier handshapes is unique to each signed language. This project uses existing sign language assessment tools to determine whether the signers have developed conventions for the use of classifier handshapes. Like classifier constructions, directional verbs also make use of space. However, rather than marking locative relations, directional verbs use space to represent the grammatical relations of subject and object—who does what to whom. In other emerging sign languages, directional verbs have been shown to develop gradually as the language is passed down from generation to generation. This research project asks whether the transmission of the language among members of the family has supported the emergence of directional verbs. Classifier constructions and directional verbs have been argued to represent the interface of grammatical structure with non-linguistic gesture. To determine the contribution of gesture to the emergent structure of the language, this research project also examines the gestures produced by hearing, non-signing individuals from the larger community. Altogether, this project aims to tease apart the contributions of a variety of factors to the process of language emergence, including: an individual's capacity to create language, transmission of a sign system from individual to individual, and the role of the gestural practices of the ambient speech community. This research contributes to our understanding of the human language capacity and raises awareness about sign languages.

por.por_cntn:
Suppose a group of individuals were to create a new language from scratch. What would that language look like? Most spoken languages offer little insight into this question because their origins lie in prehistory. To observe the process of language creation directly, scientists must look to sign languages, which continue to be created in the present day wherever a community of deaf individuals forms. When a deaf child who cannot hear spoken language does not have the opportunity to learn an existing sign language, he or she may create a homesign system, an idiosyncratic sign system that exhibits many, but not all, of the fundamental properties of conventional languages. In some cases, deaf individuals come together to form a community, and their communication systems will form the beginnings of a new sign language. Most studies of emerging sign languages have focused on sign languages used by large communities of deaf individuals, either centered around a school for the deaf or in rural communities with high rates of hereditary deafness. However, there is a growing body of literature on sign languages developed by small numbers of individuals, for instance, by several deaf siblings in a family. What kinds of linguistic structures emerge in this situation? How does a sign language used by several deaf individuals compare to the homesign system of one deaf individual, or to a sign language used by a community of hundreds to thousands of people?

My dissertation research investigated the structure of a “family homesign system” created by three deaf siblings and four of their hearing family members in an indigenous community of Mexico over the past five decades. Importantly, each member of the family has different social and linguistic experiences. As part of this research, I spent a total of 18 weeks living with this family, which allowed me to gain an in-depth understanding of how they communicate in their everyday lives. Based on my observations of patterns of interaction, the sign language skills of each member of the family, and the signers’ own beliefs about their sign language, I developed a model of this family as a small signing community. This model was used to make predictions about how different members of the family would vary in their use of the family homesign system. To study the structure of the family homesign system, I asked the signers to describe various images and short video clips.

The first aim of my research was to examine the relationship between the number of language models that each signer had in childhood (i.e. older signing relatives) and the grammatical properties of their sign systems. For instance, the first-born deaf signer had no conventional sign language models. By contrast, her younger deaf brother had three sign language models (two older deaf siblings and a hearing, fluent-signing sister). I have examined the effects of the number of language models in two domains: (i) the representation of motion and (ii) strategies for representing the subject and object of a sentence. In both of these domains, there are clear differences between the older and younger signers. These differences can be summarized as an increasing preference for sequential structures in the younger signers who had multiple language models. That is, the younger signers tend to employ a separate sign for each component of an event, resulting in a more explicit representation of the structure of the event.

The second aim of my research was to assess how the social structure of the family influences the degree to which the family homesigners converge on a shared vocabulary, including (1) size-and-shape specifiers, and (2) classifier handshapes. Previous research has shown that there is a higher degree of lexical conventionalization among homesigners who are in contact with one another than among homesigners who are not in contact, demonstrating that social interaction drives lexical conventionalization. However, previous research has not addressed how rates of conventionalization may vary within a family sign language according to the internal social dynamics of the family. My results show that the members of the family who sign most frequently are more likely to employ the same handshape to represent the same entity. Thus, the deaf signers exhibit the highest level of consistency, followed closely by their adult hearing peers. By contrast, the hearing children and the older, non-fluent hearing signers exhibit lower levels of consistency. Furthermore, the level of consistency is not uniform across the lexicon: size-and-shape specifiers exhibit a higher degree of conventionalization than classifier handshapes. 

This research contributes to our understanding of the factors that influence the rate and trajectory of language emergence and shows that an account of the social organization of emerging sign language communities, as well as of the language learning experiences of the individual signers, is crucial for contextualizing and interpreting quantitative investigations of linguistic structure.
